Put the rephrased passage in rephrase tags <rephrase>like this</rephrase> so that it can be automatically extracted by an inference script.

<passage>
## Helen Keller as Philosophical Case Study

Before I get to the finetuning method, I would like to do a little more work to frame how we 
should think about these questions. The idea of an English speaker that talks coherently of
senses they don't have is not unprecedented, deaf-blind authors such as Helen Keller exhibit
this behavior. [For example](https://direct.mit.edu/daed/article/151/2/183/110604/Do-Large-Language-Models-Understand-Us)
Helen writes writes about the experience of color (which she presumably has no memory of seeing):

> For me, too, there is exquisite color. I have a color scheme that is my own. I will try to 
> explain what I mean: Pink makes me think of a baby's cheek, or a gentle southern breeze. 
> Lilac, which is my teacher's favorite color, makes me think of faces I have loved and kissed. 
> There are two kinds of red for me. One is the red of warm blood in a healthy body; the other 
> is the red of hell and hate. I like the first red because of its vitality.

Not only did Keller exhibit the behavior, [she was called out by her critics](https://twitter.com/repligate/status/1607016236126466050) as a liar and a bullshitter for it. One wrote:

> All her knowledge is hearsay knowledge, her very sensations are for the most part vicarious, 
> and yet she writes of things beyond her power of perception with the assurance of one who has 
> verified every word.

[Helen's reply](https://archive.org/stream/annesullivanmacy00nell/annesullivanmacy00nell_djvu.txt) 
is as beautiful as it is scathing:

> My experience has been like that of a sailor wrecked on an island 
where the inhabitants speak a language unknown to him, and their 
experiences are unlike anything he has known. I was one, they were 
many, there was no chance of compromise. I must learn to see with 
their eyes, to hear with their ears, to think in their language, and I 
bent all my energies to the task. I understood the necessity that life 
had laid upon me, and I did not even debate with myself the probable 
success or failure of a different course. Had it occurred to me to 
build a little tower of Babel for myself and others shipwrecked like 
me, do you think you would have scaled my castle wall or ventured 
to communicate with my dumb hieroglyphics? Should you have 
thought it worth while to find out what kind of ideas the silent, 
sightless inhabitants of that tower had originated in their isolation from 
the rest of mankind? ... I suspect that if I had confined myself 
strictly to that which I knew of my own observation, without mingling 
it with derived knowledge, my critic would have understood me 
as little as he probably does the Chinese.
</passage>

<rephrase>
## Helen Keller as a Philosophical Exemplar

Prior to delineating the finetuning methodology, it is incumbent upon me to further contextualize the epistemological framework through which such inquiries ought to be contemplated. The conception of an anglophone individual articulating coherent narratives regarding sensations they ostensibly lack is not without precedent; authors experiencing deaf-blindness, such as Helen Keller, manifest this very phenomenon. For instance, Keller proffers a written exposition on the experience of colorâ€”a sensory modality she presumably retains no mnemonic record of visually perceiving:

> For me, too, there is exquisite color. I have a color scheme that is my own. I will try to explain what I mean: Pink makes me think of a baby's cheek, or a gentle southern breeze. Lilac, which is my teacher's favorite color, makes me think of faces I have loved and kissed. There are two kinds of red for me. One is the red of warm blood in a healthy body; the other is the red of hell and hate. I like the first red because of its vitality.

Not only did Keller exemplify this comportment, but she was subsequently impugned by her detractors, who levied allegations of prevarication and dissimulation. One critic opined:

> All her knowledge is hearsay knowledge, her very sensations are for the most part vicarious, and yet she writes of things beyond her power of perception with the assurance of one who has verified every word.

Keller's subsequent rejoinder was as aesthetically profound as it was trenchantly critical:

> My experience has been like that of a mariner shipwrecked on an island where the denizens communicate in a vernacular utterly foreign to him, and their collective experiences are fundamentally incongruous with his own. I was a solitary entity, they were a multitude; no possibility for compromise presented itself. The imperative was incumbent upon me to learn to perceive through their ocular faculties, to apprehend auditory stimuli through their aural organs, to engage in cognition utilizing their linguistic constructs, and I devoted the entirety of my energies to this formidable undertaking. I apprehended the necessity that existence had imposed upon me, and I did not even engage in internal deliberation regarding the probable success or failure of an alternative course of action. Had the notion occurred to me to construct a personal, diminutive Tower of Babel for myself and other similarly shipwrecked individuals, do you presume you would have surmounted the ramparts of my citadel or hazarded an attempt to decipher my mute hieroglyphics? Would you have deemed it a worthwhile endeavor to ascertain the nature of the ideations conceived by the silent, sightless inhabitants of that tower in their sequestration from the remainder of humanity? ... I conjecture that had I circumscribed my discourse strictly to that which I knew from my own unmediated observation, devoid of any amalgamation with knowledge derived from external sources, my critic would have comprehended my meaning as inadequately as he presumably comprehends the Chinese language.
</rephrase>
